examples: with ease He passed the exam with ease.
The ease with which she learns languages is astonishing.
for ease of something All important points are numbered for ease of reference (= so that you can find them easily).
This computer is popular for its good design and ease of use.
I obtained the drugs with alarming ease.
I was surprised at the apparent ease with which he got into the building.
She returned her opponent's serve with contemptuous ease.
The back of the garment is split for ease in walking.
The car brings ease of access to the countryside.

meanings.def: the state of feeling relaxed or comfortable without worries, problems or pain
examples: In his retirement, he lived a life of ease.

meanings.def: used as a command to soldiers to tell them to stand with their feet apart and their hands behind their backs
relaxed and confident and not nervous or embarrassed
examples: I never feel completely at ease with him.
She was at her ease straight away in the new job.
I felt ill at ease in such formal clothes.

meanings.def: to make somebody feel relaxed and confident, not nervous or embarrassed
examples: Try to put the candidate at ease by being friendly and informal.

meanings.def: to do or say something to make somebody stop worrying about something

idioms.def: used as a command to soldiers to tell them to stand with their feet apart and their hands behind their backs
relaxed and confident and not nervous or embarrassed
examples: I never feel completely at ease with him.
She was at her ease straight away in the new job.
I felt ill at ease in such formal clothes.

idioms.def: to make somebody feel relaxed and confident, not nervous or embarrassed
examples: Try to put the candidate at ease by being friendly and informal.

idioms.def: to do or say something to make somebody stop worrying about something

related: ease into something | ease yourself/somebody into something

meanings.def: to become less unpleasant, painful or severe; to make something less unpleasant, etc.
examples: The pain immediately eased.
ease something This should help ease the pain.
The plan should ease traffic congestion in the town.
It would ease my mind (= make me less worried) to know that she was settled.
Tensions between the two countries are beginning to ease.
The situation would be considerably eased if more money were made available.
Ramps have been built to ease access for the disabled.
They have provided valuable economic aid to ease the transition to a market economy.
His family connections eased his passage into the top ranks of the industry.

meanings.def: to move slowly and carefully; to move somebody/something slowly and carefully
examples: + adv./prep. He eased slowly forwards.
ease somebody/something + adv./prep. She eased herself into a chair.
He eased off (= took off) his shoes.
I eased myself slowly out of bed.
Jean eased back on the pillows and relaxed.
She carefully eased the car out of the garage

meanings.def: to make something less tight and more relaxed; to become less tight and more relaxed
examples: Ease your grip on the wheel a little.

meanings.def: to become or make something lower in price or value
examples: Share prices eased back from yesterday's levels.
